So, for all the enthusiasm around United’s summer business, and attempts to stir strong rhetoric, internal issues remain. Outside the club, among the fanbase, emotions are conflicted too.
On August 5, the 1958 group, which has organised a series of protests over the past few years, called for another march against the ownership ahead of the Arsenal game. A week later, following the results of a fan survey, they postponed the protest.
In between, United confirmed the signing of Benjamin Sesko in a deal worth a potential €85m (£73.4m; $99.5m). For those on the fringes of the fan protest, maintaining the anger to rally against those in charge probably becomes harder in those circumstances. The 1958 said the “fight” for accountability on decisions will continue.
Sesko got a mention during the staff meeting. Wilcox, United’s director of football, said “Benji” had shown tremendous desire to join the club, claiming he had rejected further offers of a higher salary from Newcastle United even after he had agreed personal terms at Old Trafford (a point disputed by people at Newcastle). Sesko played his first game for Manchester United on Sunday, featuring against the under-21s on a training pitch at Carrington.
Amorim took up the theme of only having players who want to be at United, praising Bruno Fernandes for rejecting the financial allure of Al Hilal in May. Fernandes could have earned much more money in Saudi Arabia, Amorim told staff, but he chose to stay and he deserves respect and love for that as United’s captain. Amorim explained that paying players what they want does not tally with running a business, so Fernandes had shown leadership in this case.
Amorim believes the new building will help keep players happy. He gave the example that, after training on Sunday, he walked through the facility to find four players enjoying a game of snooker. Armstrong, picking up on what seemed a running misunderstanding, interrupted to say he would have to explain to Amorim the difference between snooker and pool, which was what the players were actually playing. There was laughter at this lighter moment.
There is also a barber shop, an F1 simulator and a PlayStation in social areas at Carrington, additions that Amorim thinks will encourage players to spend more time there and develop better bonds with team-mates.

Amorim said he had come in on a day off to talk to staff, something that would have given him trepidation last season. He explained there were times when he did not look forward to arriving at work, which landed a little awkwardly for some of those listening who have seen colleagues leave who used to be thrilled to turn up at Old Trafford or Carrington.
But he won people round by saying he gets excited about clocking in now, and how the revamped layout at United’s training complex allows him to connect with other staff at the club across all departments in a way that was impossible before. He explained how that day he passed so many colleagues as he walked the main building, and had engaging conversations with them, adding he is keen to integrate, rather than being separate.
Amorim’s mood last season was linked to poor results. But with Sesko joining Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo in a transfer outlay surpassing £200million, he has more tools to find happiness on the pitch.
That spending, combined with talks on a possible move for Carlos Baleba at Brighton, is greater than what was anticipated at the start of the window and a reversal on the idea United needed to make sales first. It has led some with a line into the upper echelons of the club to believe Ratcliffe has sanctioned the push knowing Amorim needs a strong start to this campaign, otherwise faith in him and the football leadership will erode.
There is also Ratcliffe’s pact with the Glazers to consider, with the Americans holding an option to force a sale of his shares should they wish and find a buyer. That is partly why the petrochemicals billionaire has, in view of at least one person at the club, decided it is “now or never”.
There are similarities with Erik ten Hag’s first campaign, which started with two defeats and prompted the hurried signings of Casemiro and Antony for more than £150m in the summer of 2022. The Glazers needed Champions League qualification to maintain a healthy valuation in the club they intended to sell.
United’s current hierarchy would argue their purchases have been sober and planned, but still it is a lot of money, five months on from Ratcliffe claiming United would have been “bust by Christmas” had they not cut jobs.

The merits of that imagery are now clear, but cash does remain an issue. United are using the revolving credit facility, and appear to have extended the borrowing capacity beyond the original £300m, but generating revenue in a year when there is no European broadcast income is essential.
That is where Armstrong, appointed from Paris Saint-Germain in February, comes in. United’s chief business officer, who made a good impression during his speech, has brought all arms of income under his remit and is making a start on signing up sponsors.
Armstrong told staff that United are on the verge of announcing three new partnerships, and his team had, across the last five months, agreed £70m of deals.
One new name associated with United is Coca-Cola, which has become the club’s official soft drink partner. The deal was announced on Wednesday, two days after Armstrong spoke, and is understood to be worth around £1million per year.
The symbiosis of soft drink companies and United’s football fortunes is not necessarily direct, but reshaping the squad to Amorim’s designs does require funds from far and wide. United have taken a calculated risk by committing to extra spending now. United’s head coach needs these players to perform.

It was a Thursday afternoon and Albert Stubbins and his wife, Anne, sat contentedly in darkness through the matinee. When it was over, they took the bus home.
All the while, fever raged. Eighteen clubs were in contact with Newcastle about the transfer request Stubbins had submitted some 24 hours earlier. Stubbins, known for his deadly smoothness on the pitch — ‘the Smiling Assassin’ — was displaying some off it.
Admittedly, going to the pictures on the bus is a long way from Alexander Isak boarding a private jet to train alone in San Sebastian — prompting the exquisite ‘Basque Separatist’ headline on Tyneside — but the cases of Stubbins and Isak are sufficiently similar to bear comparison. They also tell us about how football’s culture has changed.
In September 1946, there were two clubs leading the eager 18 for Stubbins’ signature. One was Everton and, as in 2025 with Isak, the other was Liverpool. On hearing of Stubbins’ request to leave St James’ Park, representatives of both Merseyside clubs had scurried to the north east of England, and as Stubbins sat through his film, both were now ensconced in the boardroom with Newcastle United’s principal director, Stan Seymour.
The Liverpool Echo’s lead that Thursday was: ‘Newcastle’s Gold Rush: Everton and Liverpool Well Up in the Queue for Stubbins’.
Both clubs quickly reached a financial figure Newcastle would accept, eliminating all others bar Sunderland. Newcastle’s great rivals were on the telephone, bidding like this was some art auction.
The fee was £13,000 and all three clubs said they would pay it. Only one transfer in European history had cost more — Arsenal paid £14,000 to Wolves for Bryn Jones.
But that had been in 1938; this, literally, was a different world. This was the first full season after the Second World War. It was a new era for football, Europe, everywhere. The game, not war, was occupying thoughts and, reflecting that, attendances surged.

Each Merseyside club wanted to be champions of England again, the first post-war champions. Everton had been champions in the last season before the war, 1938-39. Liverpool’s last title was in 1923. Their urgency increased when losing 5-0 to Manchester United in their latest match.
Newcastle United, meanwhile, were in the Second Division. But Seymour — ‘Mr Newcastle’ — understood the business of football, and in Stubbins, 27, Seymour knew Newcastle had the most valuable asset there is: a goalscorer in his prime.
Born in Wallsend on the River Tyne, Stubbins spent his early years in the United States in New York and Detroit. He returned aged 12 and was an avid Newcastle United fan. Stubbins was about 6ft (183cm) tall with size 11 boots at a time when the UK male average height was 5ft 6in to 5ft 7in. He was unusually fast and he was brave in front of goal. He had played 218 times for Newcastle and scored 237 goals. Famed for scoring hat-tricks, Stubbins accumulated 29 of them.
The goals came mainly in wartime football, but it was still a high standard. “I can’t say I found a lot of difference between wartime and peacetime football,” he once said. He won one war-time England cap, but the formidable Tommy Lawton was England’s No 9 then.
As Sir Bobby Robson, a future Newcastle United manager, put it in his memoir My Kind of Toon: “Albert Stubbins was the Alan Shearer of his day.” Robson also said: “Albert was my first hero and my first heartbreak.”
Once the £13,000 fee had been agreed, Newcastle began calling local cinemas to see if Stubbins could be raised. He could not. A taxi was sent to his Wallsend home and returned empty. After four hours in the smoke-filled St James’ boardroom, they started playing cards.
Stubbins was clearly aware of his value and of the interest, but he told the Daily Mail that night: “I just went to the pictures with my wife and when I got home, a neighbour told me that I was wanted at the Park. So I just came back on the bus.”

When Stubbins finally arrived at St James’, he was introduced to Liverpool chairman Bill McConnell and manager George Kay, and Everton’s secretary-manager Theo Kelly. When asked by Seymour which club he would like to speak to first, Stubbins added to the day’s theatre by replying: “Let’s flip a coin. Heads, Liverpool. Tails, Everton.”
Heads won. Sunderland, who had been Stubbins’ first senior club as a youth — and Stubbins worked on Wearside as a shipyard draughtsman during the war — were discounted.
After hearing what McConnell and Kay had to say about plans at Anfield, and already having friends in the Liverpool team such as Jack Balmer, Stubbins plumped for the Reds. “In the end, I never spoke to Everton because I was so impressed with Liverpool’s offer,” Stubbins later said.
Like today, it is highly probable contact between Liverpool and Stubbins had been made quietly long before — this was his second transfer request. The delay enabled Newcastle to sign a new centre-forward, Middlesbrough’s George Stobbart, the day before Stubbins’ second request. Three weeks later, the £13,000 received at St James’ went on signing the brilliant Len Shackleton from Bradford Park Avenue. Stubbins had not had to force his way out, it was orchestrated. Newcastle did not bleat.
That said, to a 13-year-old Bobby Robson, “when Newcastle sold him to Liverpool, I felt betrayed”.
Having been in a Newcastle cinema on that Thursday afternoon, Stubbins was in Liverpool’s starting XI at Bolton 48 hours later. It was a wet day, but 35,000 turned up at Burnden Park to see Stubbins, with the Liverpool Echo reporting: “The East Lancashire Road was crowded with traffic from Liverpool to Bolton.”
It was beneath the headline: “Stubbins Winner in Mudlark”. With the teams level at 1-1, Stubbins had scored in the 82nd minute. (Although Liverpool got a third in the last seconds, the headline will have been written before then.)

It was the perfect start. Pre-television, and because of the war, so many had travelled to see Liverpool’s new striker because there was little or no footage of him. “Stubbins is a sizeable boy with a boxer’s features and a raking stride,” the Echo said. “He tells me he has no nickname, but it won’t be long before his guinea gold locks get the inevitable ‘Ginger’ from Spion Kop.”
And the following Monday, good first impressions were reinforced: “Make no mistake, Stubbins has class.”
The effect of the hype was seen on Stubbins’ home debut the next Saturday, against Everton. It was the first “all-in” derby since before the war, and the local papers reported queues from 9.30am and the closing of the turnstiles at 2.30pm. It was 0-0.
Reports refer to queueing fans — one was James McDonald from Bootle, who had first seen Liverpool play “50 years ago”. He followed both them and Everton “impartially”. Another was William Heap, a demobbed soldier who thought he could endure hours of waiting in the rain, given he had been at the Normandy landings. There was none of modern football’s grinding self-importance.
At Bolton, Stubbins had scored the first of 24 goals in his first season. Liverpool were eighth. When he scored in a 4-1 win at Sunderland in December, Liverpool were second. By the end of May 1947, they were first, Stubbins scoring the decisive goal in a 2-1 win at Wolves. Liverpool were champions. The bus fares, the cinema tickets, the wait at St James’, they had all been worth it.
Liverpool had also reached the semi-final of the FA Cup, thanks to a Stubbins hat-trick in the last eight against Birmingham. It was the day he scored his ‘Goal in the Snow’, a diving header from a Billy Liddell cross that immediately entered Anfield folklore.
Newcastle also reached the semi-final. A ‘Stubbins final’ was on, but both Liverpool and Newcastle lost. After Newcastle’s defeat, captain Joe Harvey and Stubbins’ replacement, Shackleton, went “on strike” as Shackleton wrote in his autobiography. Promises from the club had not been kept. Isak will think it sounds familiar. “What a story that was for the newspapers,” Shackleton said.

In his second season at Anfield, Stubbins again scored 24 goals. It was not enough to retain the title, though, and Liverpool dropped to 11th place.

It did not affect Stubbins’ ballooning popularity. It was such that his name crossed into local culture — “A-L-B-E-R-T, Albert Stubbins is the man for me,” was a Merseyside playground chant. One who must have heard it as he grew up near Penny Lane was John Lennon.
As Stubbins and Isak might note, Lennon lived on Newcastle Road, at number nine. He was born on October 9 and later wrote #9 Dream, which appeared on his 1974 solo album Walls and Bridges. As a sleeve note illustration Lennon used a picture he had drawn as a boy of the Newcastle-Arsenal 1952 FA Cup final. In it is a Newcastle No 9, Jackie Milburn. “It’s just a number that follows me around,” Lennon said.
Paul McCartney felt similarly, which is why, when the Beatles were compiling 71 names and faces to appear on the cover of their seminal Sgt Pepper album in 1967, the one footballer chosen was Albert Stubbins. The Beatles sent him a signed copy, McCartney sent him a telegram. “Well done, Albert, for all those glorious years of football. Long may you bob and weave.”
Stubbins was back on Tyneside then, working as a sports journalist. He had stayed six full seasons at Anfield, but although he played in the 1950 FA Cup final, there were contractual issues as early as 1948, plus injuries. He moved back to Tyneside and trained with Gateshead FC; in December 1950, Stubbins missed a Liverpool game for “domestic reasons”; in February 1951, Middlesbrough offered Liverpool £18,000, but the transfer didn’t happen.
In September 1953, aged 34, Stubbins left Liverpool to sign for non-League Ashington in the north east. For a fee of £3,000, the Morpeth Herald reported: “Albert is coming as a player-coach and in the position of centre-half, where he always wanted to play.”
That may have been news to some, but then the Liverpool Daily Post did call Stubbins “the most enigmatic fellow ever known in soccer”, shortly before he departed.
After retirement from playing, in 1960 Stubbins briefly returned to the U.S. to coach the New York Americans in the American Soccer League. A New York Times interview from then says: “‘Soccer’, Stubbins explains patiently to a non-expert inquirer, is played with eleven men on a side.”

He was back reporting on north-east action soon and did so for decades — there is a photograph of Stubbins with a young Paul Gascoigne at Newcastle’s training ground.
Stubbins stayed in touch with his Liverpool 1947 title-winning colleague, Bob Paisley, who was also from the north east. Stubbins was a living link between two football-obsessed northern English cities, one of many overlaps between the clubs, who do not share some ancient animosity, despite what August 2025 might suggest.
Kevin Keegan could tell you that — the legendary Liverpool player and revered Newcastle player and manager had his famous 1984 ‘helicopter testimonial’ at St James’ against Liverpool. Rafa Benitez is a more recent addition, beloved by both fanbases. Granted, Isak will not be quite so warmly embraced in two places should this acrimonious move be concluded.
Stubbins died in late December 2002. His funeral in Tynemouth was attended by Robson. In Newcastle United’s next home game, black armbands were worn by both teams in Stubbins’ honour.
The visitors were Liverpool.

Celtic will play no part in the league phase of this season’s Champions League after losing on penalties in the play-off round to Kazakhstani side Kairat Almaty.
The tie ended 0-0 on aggregate, with neither side being able to find a winner in extra time at Kairat’s Central Stadium.
Striker Adam Idah had his penalty saved by Kairat goalkeeper Temirlan Anarbekov, before Luke McCowan and Daizen Maeda also failed to convert as the Kazakhstan Premier League champions won the shootout 3-2. Callum McGregor and Arne Engels found the net for Celtic.

Kairat are the first Kazakhstani club to reach this stage of the Champions League since the 2015-16 season, when Astana finished bottom of the group featuring Galatasaray, Benfica and eventual finalists Atletico Madrid.
Celtic will now compete in the Europa League this season, with the draw for the competition taking place on Friday.
The club’s failure to reach the league phase of the Champions League has significant financial implications.
As part of the expansion to a 36-team format, UEFA increased the total amount of money distributed to clubs competing in the Champions League to €2.5billion (£2bn; $2.6bn). Each club receives a €18.6m starting fee and teams also receive performance-related payments depending on how far they progress in the tournament.
More money (around 35 per cent of that €2.5bn) is paid out on the basis of a club’s historic European performances and their share of the wider broadcasting market, through what UEFA calls the ‘value pillar’. Celtic will also miss out on any additional funds generated by Champions League ticket sales.

A new Champions League season is upon us. After Paris Saint-Germain finally got their hands on the trophy for the first time last campaign, clubs will once again start to battle it out to become football’s kings of Europe.
The draw for the league phase, which begins on September 16, takes place on Thursday. With Tottenham Hotspur winning the Europa League last season, there will be six English teams among the 36 sides competing in this year’s tournament.

The Athletic has put together the all-important details for the league-phase draw.
Remind me again, what is the format?
Last season, the Champions League introduced a new 36-team format which is set to be in place until at least 2027.
Rather than facing the same three sides twice as happened in the old group-stage version, this league phase has each team play eight games, all against different opponents.
For the draw, the clubs are split into four pots of eight based on their UEFA coefficient — a ranking system based on a team’s performances in UEFA competitions across the previous five seasons that helps determine their opponents for the league phase. Teams from the same country cannot play each other in this opening stage.
Following the conclusion of the league phase in January, the top eight teams in the table progress automatically into the round of 16 in March. Those that finish ninth to 24th will contest eight home-and-away play-offs in February to decide the other qualifiers for the last 16, with the eight beaten teams being eliminated from Europe for the rest of the season.
Teams are paired against two teams from each of the four pots, one home and one away. However, clubs from the same association cannot be drawn against each other, and nobody can face more than two opponents from the same association.
This changes from the knockout round, where teams from the same country can meet.
Did the league format work last season?
There were some thrills during the inaugural league phase, yes. Unexpectedly, holders Real Madrid, along with Manchester City, Bayern Munich, PSG and Juventus all finished in the play-off spots.
It did create more interesting and competitive first-stage ties. Many argued a negative of the traditional group format was that there were too many dead-rubber games in the final set of matches with the two two places in each pool already decided. But there were plenty of surprise results in the league phase — Sporting’s 4-1 thumping of City in Lisbon, Aston Villa beating Bayern at home and Dortmund thrashing Barcelona 3-1 to name just three.

The final gameday of the league phase, with all 18 matches taking place at the same time, also created drama as the league table changed multiple times and there was uncertainty around whether some of the aforementioned big-name clubs would fail to make the knockout rounds.
The surprise league-phase results also made for interesting fixtures at the competition’s business end: Liverpool finished top of the league having won their first seven games but got drawn against eventual winners PSG in a blockbuster last-16 tie after the latter came only 15th, losing three of their eight games, then beat fellow French side Brest in their play-off tie.

Why is the draw digital?
It’s to save time. UEFA says that if the entire draw were to be completed manually, around 1,000 balls would be spread across at least 36 bowls up on stage and the whole process would take more than three hours. Last year’s digital draw, using UEFA’s automated software, took around 30 minutes, starting when guest Cristiano Ronaldo pressed a button to reveal City’s eight opponents.

UEFA uses software from AE Live, a company which has provided sporting draw services for more than 20 years, including for the FA Cup, FIFA, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and CAF, African football’s governing body.
When will the fixtures be announced?
The tournament’s fixture list, including match dates and kick-off times, will be published no later than this Saturday, August 30, allowing time for the draws of UEFA’s two other annual club competitions on Friday.
The league phase matchdays start on September 16-18 and conclude with matchday eight on January 28.
How can we follow it?
The Athletic will be blogging the draw live and it will be streamed on UEFA’s official website and YouTube channel. Viewers from the United Kingdom can also find it on TNT Sports and for those in the United States, it will be on Paramount.
When and where is the draw?
The draw will take place on Thursday, August 28, at the Grimaldi Forum in Monaco, at 5pm BST (12pm ET).
A day later, the draws for the Europa League and Conference League will happen at the same venue, starting at noon BST.

Perhaps this particular discourse’s revival was an inevitable consequence of U.S. Soccer publishing a roster including the surname “Klinsmann.” Perhaps it was Mauricio Pochettino’s pet cause entering Tuesday’s media availability, held to address his U.S. men’s national team squad for the September friendlies. Most likely, it’s a less conspiratorial third factor most responsible for the reopening of the longtime questions about MLS’s role in shaping the USMNT.

Throughout his tenure, which is nearing its anniversary, Pochettino has had to survey a player pool humbled by failure at last year’s Copa América and find a squad capable of doing the program proud at the 2026 World Cup. That previous core was dominated by players who play for some of Europe’s most notable clubs. Now, key members of that group — headlined by Weston McKennie, Yunus Musah, Johnny Cardoso and Antonee Robinson — will miss the fifth-to-last camp before the World Cup comes to Canada, Mexico and the United States.
Many of the players selected in those same roles hail from MLS. Several helped the USMNT reach the final of this summer’s Gold Cup, where they lost to a full-strength Mexico. At present, Pochettino estimates that his player pool includes “60 to 65” options, perhaps a worryingly bloated scale with a World Cup just under 10 months away. Still, his recent preference for options in MLS has sparked debate about the efficacy of a league — still well outside of the world’s absolute top circuits — to prepare players to excel on the grandest stage.
“We need to give MLS the value, because I think competing there, I think players can show that they can perform in the national team,” Pochettino said on Tuesday. “I think it’s not necessary to move from MLS to Europe. Because sometimes MLS, under my assessment, maybe is more competitive than some leagues in Europe.”
It’s a sentiment sure to rile certain sects of U.S. fandom who long craved a manager with Pochettino’s European pedigree and likely expected that he would maintain a different preference. It’s one that stands in direct opposition to what was voiced by Jurgen Klinsmann during his tenure as U.S. manager. Upon succeeding Bob Bradley in the role, Klinsmann aggressively looked for dual-national options (largely those in Germany) to bolster his player pool. He also openly questioned MLS’s caliber and often mused about whether a league outside of the game’s highest levels offered proper schooling for a program determined to return to the business end of a World Cup.

When star players Jozy Altidore, Michael Bradley and Clint Dempsey moved to MLS, Klinsmann questioned the ambition of their moves. Many fans embraced the coach’s narrative. Any subsequent roster released over the past decade including a healthy dosage of MLS talent was scrutinized, with many vocal detractors fixating on which MLS players were called in with minimal critical thought about the state of the pool.
Never mind, of course, that Klinsmann’s infamous omission of Landon Donovan saw him opt for Brad Davis, a career MLS winger, or that eight of the 13 USMNT players whom Klinsmann played for at least 100 minutes at the 2014 World Cup were on MLS rosters. It’s a talking point that has echoed loudly and often since his dismissal in late 2016.
MLS is inarguably in a better state now, over a decade on from Klinsmann’s group reaching the round of 16 in Brazil. The league restructured its approach to youth development in the late 2000s and has since dependably produced MLS-level players throughout its 30-team ecosystem. Some, like Tyler Adams and Ricardo Pepi, began their pro careers with their boyhood clubs and have remained relevant for European clubs and the USMNT alike. Others, like McKennie, Gio Reyna and Chris Richards, spent time in MLS academies before going pro across the Atlantic.
That isn’t to say that MLS has cracked it, of course; that work remains wholly in process. What’s different now compared to Klinsmann’s tenure is that MLS has closed the gap some and is more comparable to some of Europe’s more famous leagues beyond the Big Five. That’s how Pochettino sees it.
“We have some players competing in different leagues [that] maybe are not so competitive,” Pochettino said, “or in (a league that) every single week compete(s) in the same way that you compete in MLS every single week … ‘Oh, if you play in a team in Europe, you are above the players that are in MLS.’ That is not the way to assess.”

There’s no definitive pecking order for the world’s top leagues, but Opta has a formula that tries to compare circuits from across the world. As of June, Opta ranked MLS as the 12th-strongest league in the world via its data-driven Power Rankings, which averages the 1-to-100 ratings of all teams within a league. MLS’s score of 78.5 puts it in close proximity to Liga MX and the first divisions in Argentina, the Netherlands, Japan, Croatia and Denmark. The English Championship ranks sixth, perhaps surprisingly ahead of all of those leagues as well as Portugal’s first division.
It’s another data point to suggest that MLS is at least of a competitive caliber similar to those leagues that are more widely agreed to be definitive members of the club game’s second tier. The league itself has its trademark features and flaws. Many teams still play with a dedicated No. 10, a fading facet of the game in Europe. The league’s rules encourage teams to prioritize investing in attacking players. To briskly assess, that leaves MLS with a lower standard of defending than other leagues in that “Best of the Rest” category.
Those roster rules also encourage MLS teams to lean into domestic talent, an obvious benefit for players from the U.S. and Canada. With a limit on international signings and designated players, teams will be more inclined to consider domestic options in luxury roles (like striker, attacking midfield and central midfield) than leagues better equipped to spend throughout their entire squad.
It’s a factor that has helped bolster Diego Luna’s case for inclusion. After impressing Pochettino in January camp, the 21-year-old has benefited from consistent starts as a playmaking midfielder for Real Salt Lake. So while Luna received some interest from clubs in Mexico and Europe this summer, leaving a stable situation less than a year before the World Cup looked like too great a gamble.
“When it comes to moving teams with such a small amount of time coming into the World Cup, it’s difficult,” Luna told The Athletic in July. “You don’t know where you’re going to play, when you’re going to break through, how you’re going to make it work, or if it’s just going to stall for six, eight months. You don’t know if you have that type of time right now. There’s a bunch that plays into it, because the World Cup is a huge thing, and everybody wants to be a part of it.”
It’s a perk that helped turn Paxten Aaronson’s head, too. The 22-year-old left his boyhood Philadelphia Union for Eintracht Frankfurt in January 2023, playing far more on Eredivisie loan stints with Vitesse and Utrecht. Aaronson was selected for the Gold Cup squad, but earned just 11 minutes across two late-game shifts. Luna and Malik Tillman were preferred, while older brother Brenden also saw meaningful time in the same roles. Those 18 months in Holland still hadn’t raised his level enough in Pochettino’s eyes.
The Colorado Rapids came calling after the Gold Cup, fresh off of their $8 million transfer of U.S. international Djordje Mihailovic to Toronto FC. The attack needed a new key figure, and the club, typically frugal operating under the Kroenkes’ stewardship, had new resources to reinvest. After speaking with head coach Chris Armas and chief soccer officer Padraig Smith, Aaronson surprised the USMNT ecosystem by returning to MLS and on a $7 million initial transfer fee.

“I think it’ll challenge me as a young player to come into a team, to fight for trophies, to get better in roles and aspects maybe Europe can’t give me,” said Aaronson, who was not included by Pochettino for the upcoming window. “Yeah, I think that’s the main thing that attracted me to it: coming to a team, being a presence to try to win trophies and make myself better and also everybody around me.”
In 14 Bundesliga appearances, Frankfurt predominantly played Aaronson as a right winger; however, Aaronson and Armas both stated that they saw the player’s best role as being a central one. It’s a better fit for how he reads the game and how Armas hopes to get the most out of his new rising star. It’s also a role with vital responsibilities in all phases, and one Aaronson would’ve struggled to get meaningful minutes in if he hadn’t moved to a club with that specific need.
Some of this is also intrinsic. Right now, a number of prominent players on the USMNT who are in Europe are rotational pieces, often alternating between the lineup and the bench while playing the game’s less sexy roles. For players like Luna and Aaronson, who want to get a central figure’s time on the ball but didn’t come up in a European academy, MLS is a credible option where teams may build around them and look at them for well over 2,000 minutes in key positions. That’s invaluable preparation for an aspiring national team member.
Still, it’s curious to see Columbus homegrown Sean Zawadzki — who mostly plays as a center back — preferred by Pochettino for a midfield role over former Crew teammate Aidan Morris, who won two MLS Cups and was among the EFL Championship’s best two-way midfielders with Middlesbrough in 2024-25, or Tanner Tessmann, who left FC Dallas in 2021, captained the Olympic team and now anchors the Lyon midfield (and that’s to say nothing of McKennie, Cardoso or Musah). Another Crew player, Max Arfsten, has been wholly unconvincing as a makeshift fullback and continues to play as an attacking wingback for his club. And yet, his track record of inclusion suggests he may be Pochettino’s preferred alternative to Robinson in a back four.
These selection debates are eternally worth having about every international squad, including the one Pochettino called in for September. They’re also more productive than blindly writing off all players from one league — especially one that, as of recently, has seen its players (like Luna and goalkeeper Matt Freese) provide the USMNT with needed moments of excitement in what’s been a rather bleak stretch for the program. No matter what the public sentiment may be regarding MLS and its presence across the USMNT, Pochettino has shown he is more than comfortable backing the domestic league’s strength as he combs through his player pool at this most vital of junctures.

“From the moment that I arrived, I could feel the positive energy and family environment that the club has created. It is clearly the perfect place to reach my maximum level and fulfil all of my ambitions.
“I cannot wait to start learning from Ruben (Amorim, head coach) and connecting with my team-mates to achieve the success that we all know we are capable of together.”
United’s director of football Jason Wilcox added: “Benjamin possesses a rare combination of electrifying pace and the ability to physically dominate defenders, making him one of the most exceptional young talents in world football.
“We have followed Benjamin’s career closely; all of our data analysis and research concluded that he has the required qualities and personality to thrive at Manchester United.
“Working under the guidance of Ruben and our excellent performance team, Benjamin is joining the perfect environment to support him to reach his world-
class potential.
“The desire that all of our new signings have shown to join the club this summer highlights the appeal and stature of Manchester United as we continue to build and develop a team capable of challenging for the biggest honours.”

Sesko scored 21 goals in all competitions for Leipzig last season. He has recorded has recorded 39 goals and eight assists in 87 appearances for the Bundesliga team since joining from RB Salzburg in 2023.
Sesko is United’s latest addition to their forward line this summer, following the signings of Matheus Cunha from Wolverhampton Wanderers and Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford.
Why Sesko?
Analysis by Carl Anka from ‘Are Manchester United right to pick Benjamin Sesko as their main striker target?’
In 2025, Sesko has developed into a sledgehammer of a striker. He combines straight-line speed, powerful finishing and sheer bloody-mindedness to become a forward that centre-backs hate playing against.
A speedy, 195cm/6ft 5in striker who spent a brief period tearing up the Austrian league before moving to the Bundesliga, Sesko has earned some comparisons to Erling Haaland. Sesko is not quite at that level, but has plenty of the raw materials to suggest he could reach it.
His shot map from 2023-24 illustrates a striker happy to go for goal wherever and whenever. Left foot, right foot, headers. Long-range cannons and plenty of pingers within the penalty box.
Sesko is a confident striker, but is lacking the consistency needed to become a prolific one. He is prone to forcing the issue when in front of goal, hammering the ball with extra venom when trying to make it through a crowd of bodies.
His right-footed finishes when shooting from the left half-space need work, as does his movement within the six-yard box, but he has the presence and quickness of mind to have defenders regularly second-guessing themselves.
How much will Manchester United’s new attack cost?
Analysis from football finance writer Chris Weatherspoon
Spending a little over £66m on Sesko takes United’s summer outlay on guaranteed fees alone to £193.9m across three forwards, with a further £13.4m potentially payable to clubs in future add-ons.
Advertisement
Tag on estimated agent fees and the four per cent transfer levy all Premier League clubs have to pay on incoming transfers, and their spending on new players is easily over £200m.
In that sense, this is just what we’ve come to expect from United, both before and after Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s February 2024 arrival. Using financial years spanning July 1 to June 30, United spent £247.4m in 2022-23, £220.7m in 2023-24 and an enormous £343.5m in 2024-25 — the largest single-season spend in club history and the third largest in English football history (albeit that includes Matheus Cunha’s arrival, as he signed up in June).
As with every transfer, United won’t take the full hit of Sesko immediately, with his transfer costs spread across the duration of the contract he signs. But it all adds up to huge ongoing expenditure from a club whose transfer fee amortisation bill (the annual impact of spreading transfer fees) was already nearing £200m.
United have fewer PSR troubles than once thought but cash has been rather tighter at Old Trafford recently. Payment terms on Sesko are unknown, but Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo’s deals are staggered across three and four instalments respectively, helping United manage liquidity. As well, as The Athletic detailed yesterday, there are other funding options available to the club to help foot a transfer bill which shows little sign of reducing.

It is just 90 days since Paris Saint-Germain claimed their first Champions League with a 5-0 thrashing of Inter… and now the draw for the 2025-26 edition is upon us.
Plenty has changed in the interim. Managers have come and gone, hundreds of millions have been spent (and that’s just at Liverpool) and Chelsea have somehow become world champions despite not even being part of Europe’s elite competition last season.
Advertisement
So, with the Champions League line-up for this year’s tournament now complete ahead of today’s draw in Nyon, how do we assess each of them? This is our definitive — but also entirely subjective, and extremely debatable — ranking.
36. Kairat Almaty
The most easterly team to ever reach this stage of the Champions League, Almaty is closer geographically to Tokyo than it is to England. It is further east, in terms of longitude, than Mumbai. But its remote location is potentially the best chance they have of causing any upsets: the Opta Power Rankings have them as the 473rd best team in the world, which puts them one place below Italian Serie B outfit Monza, and below Luton Town.
35. Qarabag
Qarabag have only been in the group stages of the Champions League once before, and this is where the ‘new’ format has its advantages for the smaller sides: they’ve got more of a chance of making the knockouts than when the Azerbaijanis were drawn against Roma, Chelsea and Atletico Madrid in 2017-18. They also have the longest-serving manager in the competition, Gurban Gurbanov having been in charge since 2008.
34. Pafos
Another Champions League debutant, Pafos FC are a pretty remarkable story, if only because they were only formed two days before the 2014 World Cup, the result of a merger between AEP Paphos and AEK Kouklia in the Cypriot second division. Owned by Russian billionaire Sergey Lomakin, Pafos beat Red Star Belgrade in the qualifiers thanks to a dramatic goal from Brazilian winger Jaja. He’s not the only Brazilian in their side: you’ll probably be more familiar with David Luiz, who signed for them this summer.
33. Bodo/Glimt
The northernmost team in Champions League history, Bodo/Glimt have become a relative stalwart of the more minor European competitions in recent years, probably best known for humiliating Jose Mourinho’s Roma in the Conference League group stages in 2021. Managed by Kjetil Knutsen, perennially linked with jobs in England, the Norwegian side are the definition of a banana skin draw for teams not keen on playing football in the Arctic Circle.
Advertisement
32. Copenhagen
One of the more interesting, low-key transfers of the summer was Youssoufa Moukoko’s move to Copenhagen: once thought of as a wunderkind at Borussia Dortmund, the striker’s star has fallen and this feels like it could be something of a reset. Few will fancy them to progress, but they did get to the knockout rounds in 2023-24, so they’re a potential outside bet to qualify.
31. Olympiacos
Conference League winners in 2024, Olympiacos were Greek champions last season after what was, for them at least, an unthinkable dry spell of two seasons without a league title. They’re enjoying an uncharacteristic period of managerial stability (this is Jose Luis Mendilibar’s third season in charge), their squad is a mishmash of names you half-recognise. Gelson Martins! Roman Yaremchuk! Remy Cabella!
30. Slavia Prague
Automatic qualifiers after winning the Czech title last season, this is Slavia Prague’s first appearance in the Champions League proper since 2019-20. Without wishing to be unkind, they will be the sort of team the big teams will hope to get: a manageable away trip for most teams, against a side they will expect to beat with relative ease.
29. Club Brugge
Club Brugge surprisingly got to the last 16 of the Champions League last season, before they were thrashed by Aston Villa. But since then they have lost three key players — Ardon Jashari, Maxim De Cuyper and Chemsdine Talbi — and winger Christos Tzolis could be on his way out too. Given that level of upheaval, even being at this stage is a success.
28. Galatasaray
Galatasaray are, quite rightly, proud of the fact that they’re the only Turkish side to ever win a European trophy, and while they’re very unlikely to double that tally this season, they are a decent bet to qualify. They have lost just seven league games over the last three seasons, and with Victor Osimhen now signed up permanently and Leroy Sane feeding him from the wing, they will be a lively proposition.
27. Union SG
Union Saint-Gilloise finished the regular Belgian season in third place, 13 points behind Genk… but still emerged champions, thanks to the labyrinthine structure of the Belgian play-offs. But they remain one of the more remarkable success stories of European football, that title being their first since 1935. This will be their first ever appearance in the Champions League: how extraordinary it would be if they go one step further.
Advertisement
26. Benfica
Benfica’s capacity for regeneration is remarkable, usually losing at least one big player a year (it was Alvaro Carreras this summer, off to Real Madrid for €50m), and still consistently making the knockout stages of European competitions. With the exciting Greek forward Vangelis Pavlidis leading the line this time, they’re in with a chance of extending that record.
25. Sporting
Last season Sporting were almost completely derailed by the departure of Ruben Amorim to Manchester United: they had taken 10 points from their first four Champions League games before he left, but in their remaining four only managed one point, scraping into the playoffs where they were beaten by Borussia Dortmund. They still managed to win the Portuguese title and have some talents such as defender Ousmane Diomande, but the question this season is how they will cope without Viktor Gyokeres’s 54 goals in all competitions.
24. Monaco
If you want eye-catching signings that could go either way, Monaco is the place to look this summer. They brought in Paul Pogba, Ansu Fati and Eric Dier, the first two of whom are perhaps the epitome of ‘high upside’ recruits. Perhaps their success will rest on whether they keep hold of exciting winger Maghnes Akliouche and midfielder Soungoutou Magassa, who at the time of writing are still there, but that could change by transfer deadline day.
23. Villarreal
The question about Villarreal this season is whether they will have enough punch up front, following the departure of Thierno Barry to Everton and the imminent transfer of Yeremy Pino to Crystal Palace. They finished fifth in La Liga last season, their best for some time, but you wonder whether they will be able to repeat that.
22. Borussia Dortmund
Borussia Dortmund’s status as Germany’s second club has slipped significantly in the last couple of years, but Niko Kovac stabilised them last season after a difficult start. It will be interesting to see how Jobe Bellingham fits in after treading the same path as his brother, and centre-forward Serhou Guirassy could score plenty this season.
21. Ajax
Ajax only needed six points from their final five games to wrap up the Eredivisie title last season, but somehow managed to make a mess of it, leading to coach Francesco Farioli tearfully resigning. John Heitinga has returned to replace the Italian, but with a relatively uninspiring squad, will they have much impact in Europe?
20. Eintracht Frankfurt
In the last two windows they have lost Omar Marmoush and Hugo Ekitike, their bank balance thus bulging, and their recruits have mostly been ‘shrewd’, relatively low-key additions from other Bundesliga teams. Therefore, they’re one of the more interesting sides in the Champions League this season: will they be able to cope with so much change?
Advertisement
19. Marseille
Last season’s non-PSG Ligue 1 title winners (they finished second, 19 points behind the champions, in what was essentially a different division) still have Roberto De Zerbi in charge. Whatever happens, it won’t be dull.
18. Atalanta
Are Atalanta a little high, considering they’re a team managed by Ivan Juric, who won two of his 16 games in charge of Southampton last season? Perhaps, but they are a team who have constantly surprised European competition over the last few years. The question is whether they will be able to cope without the architect of their recent success, Gian Piero Gasperini.
17. Newcastle United
Football fans across the continent are giddy with anticipation to see how Alexander Isak will get on as he returns to the Champions League with Newcastle. No wait, that line was written in July, scrap that. Yep, Newcastle remain a bit of an unknown quantity until they know if they’ll have Isak or indeed any striker of note. Should get an easier draw than last time, at least.
16. PSV
After dramatically winning the Dutch title on the final day of last season, this PSV squad has undergone some significant changes, with Malik Tillman, Noa Lang and Johan Bakayoko all departing. One to keep an eye on is winger Ruben van Bommel, who shares his father Mark’s name, but not many of his playing characteristics.
15. Tottenham Hotspur
What on earth to expect from last season’s Two-Face; i.e. the Europa League winners or the 17th-best team in the Premier League? Well, goals from set pieces presumably, under new boss Thomas Frank. There’ll be specific tactical plans tailored for individual matches too, in a bold new brainwave. Frank’s first venture into the Champions League will be fascinating, although a small squad may hinder him.
14. Athletic Club
You could make a decent argument that the most significant signing of the summer in Spain, maybe even beyond, was not a new arrival, but Nico Williams agreeing to stay in Bilbao. It was assumed that he would be off to Barcelona, but now that he has stayed, Athletic will back themselves to qualify, maybe even for an automatic spot in the knockout phase.
13. Juventus
Not the force they were. Scraped into the Champions League on the final day by finishing fourth in Serie A, while they lost to PSV in the knockout phase play-offs in last year’s Champions League. Difficult to envisage anything much better under Igor Tudor, although Jonathan David and Joao Mario are decent additions.
Advertisement
12. Bayer Leverkusen
Plenty of clubs have undergone significant change this summer, but perhaps none more than Bayer Leverkusen. Florian Wirtz, Jeremie Frimpong, Granit Xhaka, Jonathan Tah and, most significantly, Xabi Alonso have all gone. Nobody expects Erik ten Hag to recreate Alonso’s success, but will he be able to even get close to it after all of this disruption?
11. Inter
It was only a few short months ago that Inter were in the Champions League final, but the prospects of a repeat look far-fetched. PSG made Inter look like Dad’s Army that night, although the departure of head coach Simone Inzaghi hasn’t been followed by a dismantling of that squad. New boss Cristian Chivu has added a few younger faces, but Inter remain a big unknown due to that dugout change.
10. Atletico Madrid
Almost guaranteed to impressively navigate the group stage while going under everyone’s radar, then when the draw for the last 16 is made they’re described as “really tough opposition, that’s not an easy draw for Team X, you know exactly what you’re going to get with a Diego Simeone team”. And then Atletico will heroically lose on penalties.
9. Napoli
The 2023 quarter-finalists look a decent bet to match that this time around, with Antonio Conte still in charge having led the team to the Scudetto last season. Conte does not have a glorious history in the Champions League but he has kept his title-winning team together and added Kevin De Bruyne. Either way, expect a rowdy Naples to be the proverbial ‘tough place to go’.
8. Chelsea
Chelsea are back in the Champions League after two seasons away, their longest gap since the pre-Roman Abramovich era. In those two years they’ve proved their mettle by winning a prestigious new competition, but aside from their Conference League success they also won the Club World Cup. Dark horses.
7. Arsenal
Quarter-finalists two years ago, semi-finalists last year… what chance of Arsenal, just like in the Premier League, making almost continual progress in Europe, too? Well, their squad looks far better prepared to cope with the inevitable injury issues they’ll suffer. Again, like in the league, their fate may depend on the form of Gyokeres.
6. Manchester City
City have a complicated history with this competition and it remains an underachievement by Pep Guardiola to have only won it once in his nine years at the club. If Guardiola has fixed City’s midfield, expect them to go all the way… to the quarter-finals where they’ll lose to Real Madrid.
Advertisement
5. Bayern Munich
Untouchable in the Bundesliga and with one of the best front threes in Europe (Harry Kane, Luis Diaz and Michael Olise), but Bayern look a little light at the moment, an opinion voiced by Kane last week. While their knockout stage credentials are unquestionable, it’s hard to make a case for this squad and manager Vincent Kompany taking them all the way.
4. Liverpool
The English champions are probably the most likely winner from the Premier League. They sauntered through the early stages last year before getting pretty unlucky by drawing PSG in the last 16, but their squad is much improved now. Even their 16-year-old back-up players are utterly brilliant.
3. Real Madrid
This is their competition. The 15-time tournament winners always turn up for the Champions League; they could field their under-16s and still make it to the knockout stages. They were undone by Arsenal last year, though, and have responded to a poor season the only way they know how, spending loads of money. Adding three new defenders and an Argentine wonderkid in Franco Mastantuono means they’ll surely be there or thereabouts again.
2. Barcelona
They haven’t won the competition – or reached a final – for 10 years but if they continue last season’s ridiculous goalscoring form (they were top scorers in the Champions League and netted 102 in La Liga, 24 more than anyone else), Lamine Yamal keeps being brilliant and tighten up their defence a little, it could be their year.
1. Paris Saint-Germain
The reigning champions are undoubtedly favourites to retain their crown, with manager Luis Enrique and last season’s squad still in place, plus they’ve added defender Illia Zabarnyi and goalkeeper Lucas Chevalier. They were exposed by Chelsea’s direct tactics at the Club World Cup and squeaked past several English teams in 2024-25, so they’re not infallible. Plus how hungry are they for more?

Alexander Isak has been named in the latest Sweden squad for their upcoming World Cup qualifiers despite his ongoing standoff with Newcastle United.
The 25-year-old has not featured for Newcastle this term, either in preseason or in the club’s opening two games of the new season – the 0-0 draw with Aston Villa and 3-2 home defeat to Liverpool.
Advertisement
He previously spent time training at the facilities of former club Real Sociedad in Spain and has not since returned to first-team training with team-mates in Newcastle.
Despite the obvious lack of match fitness Sweden head coach Jon Dahl Tomasson has included Isak in his squad for the games against Slovenia on September 5 and Kosovo on September 8.
It remains to be seen how much, if at all, Isak — who has played 52 times for his country, scoring 16 goals — features across the two matches.
Isak’s Newcastle team-mates Emil Krafth and Anthony Elanga have also been selected, as has new Arsenal striker Viktor Gyokeres.
Isak attempted to force an exit with an incendiary social media statement last week claiming “promises” had been “broken” by Newcastle and “the relationship can’t continue”.
Liverpool previously failed with a £110million offer for the striker on August 1 with Newcastle consistent in their stance that he is not for sale.
Isak scored 27 goals in 42 appearances for Eddie Howe’s side last season, finishing as the Premier League’s second highest goalscorer behind Mohamed Salah.
Speaking after the defeat to Liverpool on Monday, Howe called for “clarity” and said he wanted to work with players “that want to play” for the club.
“I’ve not been party to talks on this for a long time now. I’ve been preparing the team and giving all my energy to the players that want to play for Newcastle. I think that is where my energy is best put at the moment,” Howe said.
“We want clarity, we want to move forward, we want the narrative to change because we’re in the start of the season now.”
Could Newcastle block Isak’s call-up?
Any club found to be blocking a player’s call-up, in theory, can face sanctions from FIFA.
“Clubs are obliged to release their registered players to the representative teams of the country for which the player is eligible to play on the basis of his nationality if they are called up by the association concerned,” state the world governing body’s regulations.
The release of players for all international windows in FIFA’s international match calendar under those terms is “mandatory”, the rules add.

As the quiz question goes, “Which is the only team which plays every match away from home?”
Grimsby Town Football Club are not even located in Grimsby. Their ground is in Cleethorpes, the seaside town next to the fish docks of Grimsby in North East Lincolnshire, halfway up England’s east coast.
It’s a quirk that sums up this football club, my football club; the League Two club who knocked Manchester United of the Premier League out of the Carabao Cup in such dizzying, dramatic fashion on Wednesday night.
Advertisement
We literally have the word ‘grim’ in our name, we wear black and white stripes (“Oooh it’s just like watching Juventus”), carry inflatable fish (that’s Harry the Haddock, by the way) and sing incessantly about the industry that once made Grimsby the world’s largest port (“yes we do, yes we do”). The chant “all Town aren’t we” is not a question. It’s a statement, maybe even a state of mind sometimes.
You could hear it from the supporters at Blundell Park when the world’s most famous football team rolled into town, all smiles and anthem jackets, lolling around on the grass before kick-off. “We have smaller teams in Portugal too,” said United head coach Ruben Amorim in his pre-match interview with ITV, which showed the game live on free-to-air television in the UK. Not like this, you don’t.
The players were so close together in the tunnel that the officials had to sidestep their way between them. The Main Stand, where the dugouts are, still retains features dating back to 1901. The fans in the Pontoon, the stand behind the goal where the penalty shootout happened, can lean over the advertising hoardings and hammer on them. To say the away dressing room is compact would be an understatement.
Town’s ground, built in 1899, is squeezed in between two rows of terraced houses, with the Humber Estuary behind it. They had to close the car park on Tuesday, all 20-odd spaces of it, to accommodate the TV companies’ outside-broadcast trucks.
Grimsby Town vs Manchester United, after all, was live on both ITV and subscription-service Sky Sports in the UK. And then it rained so intensely that the television pictures were briefly interrupted, particularly in the immediate vicinity of the stadium, and the ball occasionally got stuck on the pitch, as stodgy as a tub of mushy peas. Typical.
Advertisement
But no matter. Grimsby did just what Amorim and his little tactics board couldn’t and got up and at United, submitting the defence to aerial bombardment and inducing outright panic. A two-goal lead could (should?) easily have been 3-0, and they had the ball in the back of the net four times, with two goals disallowed, before the visitors woke up. Then, after United drew level in the last minute of the 90, the so-called ‘minnows’ took a breath and won 12-11 on penalties to create pure pandemonium.
Grimsby, though, have form for bringing bigger teams crashing down to earth.
My dad, my sister and I went to Anfield to watch them against Liverpool in the third round of the League Cup in October 2001. Phil Jevons popped up with the most unlikely 30-yard last-gasp winner and created bedlam in the away end. Twenty years ago, it was Tottenham Hotspur who slipped up in the same competition, at Blundell Park, thanks to a last-minute goal from Jean-Paul Kamudimba Kalala, or JP Kalala as we called him.
In 2023, Grimsby reached the quarter-finals of the FA Cup, felling five teams from higher divisions on their way to a defeat at top-flight Brighton & Hove Albion. And on Wednesday, a squad costing less than £2million, total, beat one from three tiers higher up who have spent more than £300million trying to assemble a side. If that doesn’t tell you about the hope and possibilities of the English football pyramid, nothing will.
We have yo-yoed up and down the divisions, crashing out of the Football League in 2010, then again in 2021. But we still used to take hundreds of fans, sometimes more than 1,000, to games in the non-League fifth tier of English football. Some of them even stayed off the pitch at the final whistle.
A new era began when local businessmen Jason Stockwood and Andrew Pettit took over in May 2021 and a proud football town got its club, its soul, back. Promotion to the Football League followed a year later. Under head coach David Artell, Grimsby are unbeaten in League Two this season after five games, having won three and drawn two.
Advertisement
Grimsby is not a place without its problems, far from it.
Last year, it was dubbed Britain’s “worklessness capital” after a documentary cited the high number of people claiming benefits. The less said about the 2016 Sacha Baron Cohen film titled Grimsby, the better.
The thing about Grimsby is you never pass through it. Geographically, it’s stuck out on its own. You have to drive down England’s most boring motorway, the M180, then suffer the grating concrete hell of the A180, or weave your way across the flat fields of Lincolnshire, or catch a train from Doncaster — like lots of Yorkshire folk have done over the years on a sunny day — to get there.
But it’s our place and Grimsby Town is our football club (even if, like me, you’re from the other side of the Humber — it’s a long story). There’s such pride in those distinctive black and white stripes, and no small amount of defiance either. We’re the Mariners, and “We only sing when we’re fishing”.
If you drive down Cleethorpes seafront, past the chip shops and the slot-machine arcades, the boating lake and the world’s smallest pub, turn left and then left again, you come to the Greenwich Meridian line. This is the point where east meets west; zero longitude. It’s 2,517 miles to the North Pole and 9,919 miles to the South Pole, according to the sign.
There is a statue of a globe there too, with an inscription which says: “The World revolves around Cleethorpes.”
Well, the football world did on Wednesday night. And it was utterly marvellous.
